div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager - -.R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, JANUARY 19, 1906.

It is the opinion of many authoritative person that the right of pre-emption should be wholly abolished, and we believe that it... would not be difficult to find & no justification for this standpoint. Caves do occur where do dead advantages accrue to a proprietor who acquires an adjoining property. In agri. cultural land there may be & canal or drain in joint asage which can be best utilised by one proprietor, or there may be a troublesome servitude which disappears if a compact block of land is in the hands of one mag. With building land a proprietor of a good house may real jablay ask the right to acquire an adjoining plot, on which some objectionable structura mizit bu ra: el to the depreciation of the existing property.

The essence and origin of preemption was preservation. It can be traced back to times when taxes were paid by the community and not by the individual, and consequently it was an advantage to keep on people who right fail in contributing their proper share of taxes. Also the season of the barem could only be preserved if adjoining blocks were not built upon with houses overlooking the existing premises. All this was perfectly reasonable and just, and a proprietor is entitled to be protected from injury to his property when he is quite willing to give us mach for an adjoining plot as any ontsider. Some four or five years ago the law of pre-emption was mooh modified as regards agricultural land, and it has been pat on a basis which is fairly reasonable. There must now be some very tangible reason before the law of pre-emption can be invoked over agricultural land. But in building land it isn't so, and cases are constantly arising where a parohaser, having with expense, difficulty, and sound knowledge of values, acquired a property, finds all his experience and trouble go to barich someone else. That the owner of a house should preempt enough of adjoining land to protect it from being overlooked is reasonable, but that the owner bold preempts an aros ten times more than is needed for this purpose is most adjusted. That a man interested as co-proprietor of such a bonse, or even of a building plot without a house, shoald exercise the right of pre-emption and hand-it over to someone else is iniquitous.

Pre-emption is being used now not for protective purposes, but to secara properties after other people have proved their value. There should be no lying low till value is proved and profits shown, and then try to pre-empt profits. In many cases the pre-emptor already refused the property, not trusting his own Judgment, and afterwards took it when its value was ascertained by a sale. Pre-emption claims are too often based on greed, spite, and unfair competition, very fow on real jasti. fiable protection of property. People beaten in fair competition for a property bava afterwards called in and paid an adjoining proprietor to exercise his right in their favour. The Tribadala have wisely refused to grant the right in certain casas, but the law as it stands at present is too vagao, and allows too much latitude for bringing unfounded actions.
THE STATE OF RUSSIA.

The Orthodox New Year has been celebrated in Russia without any renewal of revolutionary disorder, and if the next month can be passed quietly, the country should be safe for some little while: there will, at any rate, be no immediate peril, and the Government will have the opportunity to organise the Dama. Count Witte evidently recognises the dan. Ger of Vladimir's Day becoming an anni. mercenary, in the same way that the coloration of the Taking of the Bastille did in Pranoe after the Rorolation; and he proDiges to make further 0000689ions in the event of the 22 ad January passing peacefully. The mere fact that his promise has been stained to show that the power of the Government is on the increase. As to the constitution, the end of April has already pen fixed as a suitable date for the first tting of the National Assembly; bat this is

the assumption that there is a gradual 358ation of internal distarbanoe. The hope lat posoe will be restored seems at first sight somewhat sangiang, bat except among ne tribes of the Caucasus and the districts here nationalist sentiment keeps alive, such

Poland, there is no real reason why i. ould not. The peasants have not continued the rebellion now that the winter is at its night; and the last strike failed in the wDg. It is a weapon that recoils on its usora. Whether the Ragaian operator will take kindly

the representative machinery provided mains to be seen ; up to the present it has -hardly seemed likely. It is possible that the people will be satisfied with the shadow of war, while the anbg tanoe romans with their hereditary ruler. lo any case, these are spélations for the fatore : the main object of peace,

div.head: Cairo Postal Service.
div.p: The number of postmen in Cairo has been increased from 60 to 90.

div.head: Beni Souer Court
div.p: Mohor Bey, president of the Beni Sovet Court, has reigned and will be succeeded by Pakbri Bey, sub-president of the same Court.

div.head: Russian Cruisers
div.p: Our Suez Corro-pondent states that the Russian cruisers Errors and Oleg entered the Canal at 7 o'clock yesterday morning for PortRait.

div.head: Hashish Smuggling.
div.p: Some Arabs were discovered on the Marica yesterday in the act of smuggling & quantity of ha-hinh. They were arrested and the hashish confiscated by the police.

div.head: Cairo Ghaffirs,
div.p: The Cairo Hakemdar has decided to increase the day of goaffire from P.T. 120 to P.T. 150 per month. The new arrangement is to be considered as having come into force from the beginning of this month.

div.head: A Victim of a Drug.
div.p: A native bry of 4 years was found dead in Romleh yesterday and his body removed to hospital, where the post-mortem examination showed that death was due to swallowing a drug called "tatours monzoal."

div.head: Sugar Canes.
div.p: 'The controllers have authorised the provisional administrators of the Sucreries to page the contracts for furnishing sagar canes for the 1906 7 eeason The Hon. A. Davay has gone on an inspection tour in Upper Egypt in order to personally renew the contracts.

div.head: Experts' Fees,
div.p: The three experts chosen for the concordat preventíf of the Sucreries Company have presented a demand for a Bettlement of their account. They ask for £1,200 B-piece 88 a fee, or a total of £3,600. It has been suggested that a slip of the pen accounts for the extra zero.

div.head: Execution in Cairo.
div.p: Vo the 22nd inst., 8t 98 Abdel Malek Hussein Mabmood, a native of Dairmonas, will be executed in the prison of the Appeal Court, Cairo, for having murdered, on the 27th August last, a native woman of that village, named Shahda, because she refused to submit to his dishonourable proposals.

div.head: The Abbassieh Collision.
div.p: The railway employé killed in the Abbassieh collision was named Ibrahim Soliman. His brother is among the injured, and a brakesman named Mobamed Abmed was also born. The total material damage amounts to two locomotives and one track completely wrecked and eight tracks considerably damaged.

div.head: Concert,
div.p: A concert of more than ordinary interest will be given at the New Khedivial Hotel tomorrow afternoon, commencing at 5.15, by the pupils' of the well-known violia mastar, M. Artelli. The programme is a very attractive one, and the relatives and friends of the young musicians should turn up in fall force.

div.head: "Modern Egypt."
div.p: In our igale of yesterday we gave an account of and some extracts from Mr. William Bleroy Curtis's account of his recent visit to Egypt, both omitted to append the publishers' pote. The title of the work is "Egypt, Barms and British Malaysia" and it is published by Fleming H. Revell Company, of London and New York.

div.head: Good Bargains.
div.p: Visitors and residents who wish to obtain real bargains in Carpets, Brassware, Lamps, Mouse Rabeah, Embroideries, and Silks should go to Malluk's, Rond Point Mouski, Cairo, where the whole stock is to be sold regardless of post. As the proprietor is retiring from business. Everything will be sold; 80 do pot love the opportunity. No reasonable offer will be retired.

div.head: Sunday Closing.
div.p: The retail establishments which opened on Bandays on the occasion of the Xmas and New Year holidays, bave now resumed closing on Sanday. We are asked by the Société Internationale des Employés d'Alexandrie to state that all employés wi boat distinction are invited to attend a general meeting which will be held at the Bien Theatre tonight at 9 o'clock.

div.head: British Soldier Attacked.
div.p: A native contemporary announced that a British soldier was two days ago passing in the evening near Abdeen-street, Cairo, when he was attacked by two native thieves, wbo, master beating him severely, apatched his watch and chain and made off. His injuries are so serious that they will require twenty days' medical treatment. The thieves have been captured by the police.

div.head: Forthcoming Pianoforte Recital,
div.p: A piano recital will be given at the Savoy Hotel on the 5th inst. by M. Edouard Schweitzer, who is well-known in Paris as a pianist, and also given several very successful capitals in London, where he was warm'y acclaimed &4 an artiste of exceptional capabilities. M. Schweitzer ja & papil of M. Yarmortel and M. Pogue, and has a perfect technical knowledge of bir irstrome t, and a firm, thongh delicate, touch. It is anticipated that he will have a large audience, and indging from the testimonials which he brings with him, he should be met with great appreciation.
Spend your Bayram holidays at Mena House Hotel. [Adet.]

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.THE ELECTIONS.KEIR HARDIE AGAIN GETS A SEAT.
div.p: Mr. J. Keir Hardie, the Labour candidate or Merthyr Tydfil, has been retired for bat division for the second time.

div.head: BAL DE TETES
div.p: The Bal de Têtes given by the Cairo Comité les Pétes at Shepheard's on Wednesday was

great success though it owed little of its gala character to the Boglish guests, Not more than half a dozen of those present bad nade any attempt to appear in finoy head. 1ress other than & few flowers or a twist of anze in their coiffure, and it was rather disappointing to find that all the honours of the evening were in other hands than our. l'he big dining hall made a splendid dancing room, and the adjoining ball with its fountain Qade an inviting resting place during the earlier part of the evening, and was needed afterward: As a support-room. The decorations vore delightful, and the dancing room was Festooned with flowers and gaily coloured lights. The guests assembled soon after ten int by midnight there were over 700 present. Very few of the gentlemen had attempted anoy dress, but the bright uniforms and the lovely frocks made the scene a kaleidoscope of scintillating colours. HRH. Prince Charles William of Sweden was among the earliest Arrivals and was an energetic dancer

Mme de Vries made a most charming Print. Yo Se de Lamballe in a powdered wig with a wreath of shaded roses and long ends of soft blue velvet. There were various other headdresses of the same description, notably Mme Horwitz and Mlle. Laora Saareg. Mme. Cattani Was magnificent in a Greek costume, a loosely Draped garment of crêpe de Chine bordered with gold and a broad golden fillet crown op nor head. Mlle. Elith Cattaci made a very iprightly Pierrette with & tidy cooked bat in a plack tolle set on one side and a black ruffle around her neck. Mme. M. Cattaoi as Salammbo wore many pearls and jewels in ber fixing hair, and Mme Roms was much admired as

Flemish peasant. Both Moe. Pisober and Mme. Koressios repre cate 1 Marie Antoin tte, and Mme. Inpes and Mme. Chekri Ganem hid modelled their coiffures on the aty's of 1830. Mme. Ganzoni carried a great blue and white bird on her head, and Mlle. C. Adès wore a palate with its brass tucked in at one side using her head dredge, Mme. Reboul As a roubrette wore a pretty little cap of lace with pink Down, and Miles. Rossi and Jeanne Cohen wera delightful representations of a Wattesa Marquise and shepherd e88 respectively.

Amongst the other visitors were noticed :Major and Mrs. Wynne, Möjor and Mrs. Parsons, Capt. and Mr. Maclean, Capt. and Mrs. Bailey, Capt. and Mrs. Rome, Dr. and Mrs. Armstrong, Dr. and Mrs. Elliott Smith, Mr. and Mrs. A. V. Thompson, Mr. and Mrs. Bcott-Dalgleiab, Mrs. Preoman, Mrs. Patterson, Miss Senaoni, Miss Limpron, Miss de Vahl,! Miss French, Miss Whittaker, Misa Ambridge. Col. Watson, Major Lawson, Mr. Robertson, Mr. Stores, Dr. Brabant, Mr. Bennett, Mr. Stone, Mr. A V. Thompson, and Mr. AlexanDer Napgovich.

Mrs. Wyone was in white, as was also Miss de Vabl. Mrs. Maclean was wearing a very Fresh and dainty frock and blue chiffon taffeta. Miss Ambridge was in pink silk, and Miss French's dress was of blue chiffon with lace and pompadour insertions and garnitura of chiffon roses. Mrs. Rome was in a lovely frock of roay obiffon, the skirt inset with lace the same colour, the corsage draped with sparkling det. Mrs. Parsons was in a deep shade of cream satin, while Miss Whittaker was wearing an Empire dress of white dia. mentée gauze. Misy Lampson, whose hair was powdered, was in blue velvet, and Mrs. Thomp. Bon wore pearls in her coiffure poudré. Mrs. Patterson had on a long coat of lace over a chiffon underdress, and Mrs. Soott-Dalgleish had a long tailed pompadour corsage over a pretty lace skirt. Mrs. Armstrong was in a deep shade of heliotrope velvet, and Mrs. Freeman wore black.

There were many other pretty frocks, and one very smart one was & modified Empire in & soft white spotted gauze with a long trail of roses in heliotrope and silver across the front of the skirt. There was a tiny short bolero of old world heliotrope brocade embroidered in silver as a boudica, and from under it came two wide sash ends of the same silk which with & veiling of the gauze gave the long Empire line to the back of the frock. Another dainty dress was of pure white chiffon with three frilla of spangled lace on the skirt and a neat and small collar of the same as décolletage. A severely plain satin of deep creamy bae was embroidered with long sprays of bullion ro'99 in tarnished gold and silver through which glowed touches of softest pink.

Towards the end of the programme there speared in the ballroom a much beflowered and decorated little carriage, drawn by a mostly diminutive donkey, and as it passed among the dancers floral tsv ones were distributed to all those who were present. Dancing continued till nearly one o'clock, when about three hundred sat down to the rapper.

div.head: Moeris Hotel,
div.p: on Lake Moeris.
First Class Encampment
In connection with the Karoon Hotel Fayoum.
For particulars apply Mr. TASCO, Fayoum.

div.head:
A NEW RESTAURANT.
TO VIE WITH ANY IN EUROPE.
div.p: For the last few days Alexandrians bara noticed the Anglo-American Hotel, at the Alexandria tormings of the Ramleh Railway. is being dismantled. In fact, this hotel and restaurant, known. Currently as Santi', will soon be only a memory of the past, for it is about to be demolished to make way for a magnificent atractie, wbjob is destined to be the Ima of the finest restaurant in Alexandria.

This morning a "Gazette" representative interviewed Yebia Pachu, of the Alexandria Municipality, to whom the ground belongs, as to what he intended to do with this site, which is undoubtedly one of the finest in Alexandria. His Excellency informed our repreSentative that the iba building would be one which would vie with the most palatial of similar establishments in London or in Paris. Oa the ground floor the Pacha will instal & restaurant, a bar, and a café. He will spare no expense in fitting out the restaurant and its apparten 1088, and it will be reserved for clientèle of the biggest loss of Alexandria society. Up to now this great pity has utterly looked like a first-class restaurant: and this will therefore be a full moon. needed want. On each of the two facades there will b3 & peristyle and balcony similar to that of the Alexandria Bourse. The bar and café will also be furnished in the same style, and everything will be done to render the establishments 89 luxurious and comfortable as possi. ble. The other floors will be built so as to serve for a hotel or for saites of large flats. If it is decided to have the new Municipal Theatre on the site of the Old Ramleh station, this corner of Alexandria will become one of the best central sites in the city.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: load.lotion to those already mentioned, Augusto Foy Adib. Herr von Mobi, Capt, von Labowitz, Abbate Pacha, and M. Blue Cattaci were received in the audience by H. H. the Khedive on Thursday.
His Highness attended prayer at the Abdeen Horqau to-day.

div.head: THE MAHMAL.
div.p: A derpatch from the Emir el Hag received yesterday reports that the Mammal and its escorts, and the pilgrims accompanying it, arrived safe and sound at Jeddah at 2.30 p.m. on Wednesday.
Up to date. 19,103 pilgrims have left Shoes. of whom 11,379 are Egyptians.

div.head: THE GOVERNMENT AND THE CADI.
div.p: The Ministers met yesterday morning at Abdeen Palace, where they dealt in the pretence of the Khedive with the question of the difference which has recently arisen between the Ministry of Justice and the Mehkemeb. The decision arrived at has not yet been made public After the meeting. Ibrahim Fuad Pasha, the Minister of Justice, proceeded directly to his office at the Ministry.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: We understand that the report of a final settlement having been arrived at between the shareholders and theoreditors of the Score Ries Company is premature.

div.head: CAIRO BOURSE.
div.p: Thusban holders of the Cairo Bourse Company held & general meeting last night ander the presidency of Maurice Cattari Bay. Twe directors whose term expired, Meser-. Oziol ani A. Cattail, were re-elected, and Mr. Williamson was elected to replace Mr. M. Gillivray.

A long discussion followed the election with reference to the roost purchase of a site madı by the Brokers' Corporation. The president attempted to adjourn the discussion with a view to further negotiation with the brokers. The meeting, however, was decidedly unfavourable to an adjournment and finally voted that this committee should be given a mandate to treat with the Brokers' Corporation with reference to the purchase of a site.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Lt. Col. C. J. Markham and officers, the band of the let Batt King's Royal Rifles will perform the following programme of music on the terrace, Sher heard's Hotel, from 4 to, 6 p.m. to-morroi (Saturday) :
1 March-Bedelia --Jerome.
2 Idyll-Sizilietta-Von Rion.
3 Overture-Le Domino Noir-Arbor.
4 Ballet Music --Faust-Gounod.
5 Czardas--Zaambeki-Gung'l.
6 Cornet Solo..The Lost Chord --Sullivan, (Soloist Corpl. S. Tyler)
7 Selection-- America -- Winterbottom.
8 Valse-le Premier Baiser--Lamothe. Regimental March.-Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
Thomas Browy, Bandmaster.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Canard Line S.S. Pavia sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool with a tall garage 'including 8,381 bales cotton,

div.head: DEPARTURE OF PRINCE ARTHUR.
div.p: As already reported, the P. &0. S.S. Mongolia arrived at noon on Tuesday gaily decked with bunting, having on board H.RH. Prince Arthor of Connaught and the other members of the Garter mission en route to Japan. CongolGeneral Cameron went on board immediately on arrival, and Mastapha Ibadi Paoba, Watson Pacha, Sobalch Bey, and some of the officials of the Canal Company were received by the Prince. A double file of bluejackets from H.M.8. Diana, drawn up in front of the Canal offices, gave a royal salate, while the Coast Guards Battery fire1 the ASAAL twenty-one guns. His Royal Highness landed at three in the after. noon, and took a quarter for the evening in the Capal Company's Residency. Mongolia, with the Prince on board, left at 7 o'clock. terday morning.
Her Royal Highness Princess Looise and the Dake of Argyll, who also camo oat on the Mongolia, left by special train for Cairo shortly after four.

div.head: The Diana Leaves.
div.p: H.M 8. Diada left here to-day for Port Badan in order to take part in the official opening of the port. She has been replaced by H. M. 8. Minerva, which arrived yesterday from Alexandria.

div.head: Starving Turkish Troops.
div.p: The report that 150 Turkish troops embarked. ed at Hodeidah for Constantinoplo, retarding from Yemen, died of starvation before reaching Shoes, was grossly 6x8ggorated. There were a few deaths, but no justification for the reports in Constantinople papers that they died from chronic starvation.

div.head: Tourists.
div.p: Yesterday, by the P. and 0. Osiris, Lord Clifford, Sir William and Lady Ward, the Hon. M. Rassell, and other passengers, en Toute for Cairo.

div.head: H. M. S. Encounter,
div.p: HM. S. Racoonter, commanded by Capt. Henry V.M. Biliot, arrived yesterday on her way to join the Australian squadron.

div.head: Russian Cruisers and Transporta.
div.p: The Russian cruisers Almuz, Oleg, and Aurora arrived this morning from Vladivostok.
The German steamers Claudias, Emma, Brika, and Prento, taken over by the Russians, have been renamed Solenga, Kaligms, Sbilka, and Manguzai, respectively.
The Boglish S.S. Cheltenham, which was Boized by the Rassian, and oopfisoated, is now known as the Jboll. All the ships have been impressed into the Transport Servico.

div.head: Orderly Russlan Troops
div.p: The Russiantroops passing through are generally of very fine physique, and one could realise what a splendid force they would make if their education were less neglected. They seem absolutely devoid of any enthusiasm, their sole idea being to return home. When away from vodka they are quite orderly and obedient. An officer told me that they had not had a single row on board between Vladivostok and Port Said. Stringent precautions are taken to prevent liquor being smuggled on board,

div.head: Interesting Football Match.
div.p: Yesterday, by request of the Governor of the Suez Canal, a football match was played by a team selected from Boglish, Arabs, and Maltese against H M.S. Diana. At 3.30 his Excellency kicked off. From start to finish the match was very exciting. In the first half Port Said United did the best of the play and often looked and scored. Their forwards, however, are very weak in front of goal and seem to make little effort at combination. During the degond half the Diana had the best of the game, bats were unable to score, owing to the excelled defence of the Port Said back, and goalkeeper Williams and How together with Abrahim Zabar especially, are to be congratulated in frustrating the efforts of Dr. Jaffery, Lt Paine Dancan and Lowrie, all of whom gave a splendid exhibition of football, The matol ended in a draw. It is to be hoped that we shall see similar games in Port Ssid, and that a combined team of all nationalities will go together. The following were the teams :

div.head: EXTRAORDINARY STATE OF AFFAIRS
div.p: It is not yet known in the Payoom if the Belgian company has actually purchased the Light Railway Company or not. At all evodia bow that their inspection tour is over, things

eem to be getting back into their old Groovo Trains, being two or three hours late is an everyday occurrence, as before. Two days ago the Tamia train left that place at the ngual time, bat socially Devar rosebud Pe. youm that day at all !

I observe one of the engines is working with one cylinder only--the other being broken or part of order—and as this engine was attached to the Kalasha train on Sanday last, it stacked and refused to move -AS DO "Boecham" was available. Then was witnessed something exTraordinary, viz., station master, guard, driver, blerks, etc., and as many natives as would Lend a hand to "one in distress," uncoupled • track from the tail of this "express" and ran it back some 20 metros. After four or five attempts a start was effected, but at each station the same programme had to be resorted to. Can it be wondered as if trains are late 1 It is, however, quite impossible to gauge why the Public Works Dopt. conti
do silánt or why the Government Inspector has never been (except onoe) since last Jane.

div.head: Mixed Municipality.
div.p: Dootors bore fear that an epidemio may break out among the inhabitants of Medipot. al Payoum owing to the fact for the past 16 days they bave only had stagnant water to drink. This is dae to the pegloot of the Municipality, which, when informed by the Irrigation an. authorities that the Bahr Youssef Couple was to be closed for 16 days, did not take any precautions to supply them with spare drinking water. I cannot imagine what the males and water carta of the Municipality have been doing during thero 16 days, as all the streets are dosty. The pablo wants to know what the Municipality is doing with the money collected. ed in taxer, ets.

div.p: The Fayoum branch of the National Bank is making headway under the management of Mr. Simpson. As the work of the bank is increasing the bank has decided to select a permanent home for the Fayoum brunoh OD one of the best sites in Medinet el Fayoum.

div.head: SHOOTING IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: The Governor General of the Sodan has extended the provisions of the Preservation of Wild Animals Ordinance 80 that no person shall shoot from a steamer either at rest or in motion, or from any barge or boat attached to or being towed by a steamer, at any bird or at any animal except lion, leopard, crocodile, and, in the Bahr al-Ghazal and its tributaries only, hippopotamus.

div.head:
THE GARTER MISSION.
DEPARTURE FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: - - Prince Arther of Connaught and the members of the mission have left Port Said for Tokyo with the insignia of our highest order of chivalry, the Garter, for presentation to our august ally, the Baporor of Japan. If, therefore, there be any troth in the romoar that the Mikado felt a sense of affront when, a few years ago, this high bonjour was conferred on the Shab instead of on himself, that wound to his pride should now be beared. In any case, it is certain that the islanders of the Par Bast will warmly appreciate the lofty distinction the islanders of the Park West bestow. on the statesman and Sovereign who carried through the recent war against Russia with such splendid success. But that brilliant performance does not give the reason for his inclusion in the membership of the Most Noble Order of the Garter." Japan has become, by the evolution of circumstances, joint guarantor with Great Britain of Asiatic tranquillity, and the bestowal of the Garter may be considered, therefore, to seal the compact. It is not directed against any particular Power; on the contrary, all whose aspirations are of non-aggressive character should welcome the placing of Asiatico peace on a much more Npower basis. As regards commerce, all alike benefit by the arrangement jnat settled between Japan and China with respect to Manchuria, where all nations will stand on the same footing as traders, while China gaina greatly by being allowed time to reorganise her defensive forces on a more efficient ground plan.

Only ning or ter months bave olapre i. since the Ezyptian Estates (Limited) was formed and only £303,000 out of its half-million sterling of share capital--including the shilling Deferred Shares--hag yet been issued, but the directors now invite the subscription of £150,000 of 5 perCent. They are of the opinion that they will have no difficulty in using the proceeds with advan. tage equal to that which has attended the utilisation of the share capital already raisol. There are, of course, as yet no accounts to indicate the measure of this advantage in coal figures, but the directors describe it in general terms. They say that since the establishment of the company it has entered into many important transactions. It has become po 39888ed of various properties, comprising Agricultural land partially cultivated, building land, house property, buildings, and 80 oa, in various parts of Lower Egypt, and valas being building sites and o her pro. parties in Cairo, Alexandria, and Mansourah. The operations of the company from the first have been, they state, remarkably 890 essful the properties paribas+d having been carefully selected. Those now from singing in the company's possession are of a 8000d character, and have, in the opinion of the board, without exception, materially increased in value, in goveralia. stances sales could be nado at a considerable profit, whilst the sales already effected have yielded handsome profits to the company. In addition to purchase of property the directors have made considerable loans against adequate security at remunerativa interest. Some of gach loan is repayable at short dates, so that the money; employed shall be available, when opportunity afforded, for profit table fixed invest. ment. The directors do not seem to share the ideas that some are bold that there is a land boom in Egypt which must collapse by 730 ; on the contrary, they remark that the value of real property there is still improving. The chairm up of th's company is Mr. Groville H. Palmer, & director of the Bank of Egypt, and the dopaty-chairman is Mr. Gerald A. Sheppard, connected with the firm of Messrs. div.head: TOWARDS SALONICA.
div.p: There is something very doubtful about the quiet which is now brooding over the Balkan pepingule, and it is impossible to avoid the suspicion that some move or other is in con. temptation by the Powers interested in, which they are unwilling that the rest of the world should know of. The Constantinople correspondent of the "Vossische Zeitung" affirms that Austrian troops have already occupied the district of Plov.js, in Torkish territory, and that reinforcements are being secretly sent there. The story, of conroe, has been denied officially, but the correspondent ro tarne to the charge by recalling the fact that in October last, Austria proposed to the Porte the appointment of a Mixed Commission to decide on the exact frontier between Bosnia and the district of Plavlje, and that the Porte not only refused the proposal, but complained of the percent of Austrians in Tarkish territory. Th3 town of Pljevlja is the first place of any importance on the high road from Bosnia to Novibazar, and on the Austrian maps it is marketed as being about thirteen miles inside the frontier. If it is true that the Aastrians are laying down a line of rails from Rodow, in Bosnia, to Plovlje, it is evident that Austria has at last started on the road to Salonics, with the connivance of Russia. Who shall soon know what are really Austria': intentions towards Macedonia, and what price she has paid for the silence of Germany and Rassis.

div.head: FRANCE AND EGYPT.
div.p: According to a Rome nowdapara dispute has arisen between Franog and Eżypt, which is of considerable significance as the question of the French Protectorate over Christians in the East is involved. We have not obtained 1 any confirmation of the story, which is as follows:

Un copto avait pris à bail l'aile d'un vioax couvent appartenant à la mission maronite des moinus alpins et situé au Vieux-Caire. Tout I comment les moines constatèrent que leur locataire violait les termes du bail signé. Ils délèguent auprès de lui un des leurs pour ouvrir une enquête.

On ne sait ce qui se p898A entre le locataire et le moine délégué. Quoi qu'il en soit, le moine fut poursuivi devant le tribunal et condamné à quatre jours de prison, par défaut, pour avoir malmené et frappé le copte. .
L'absence du moine à l'audience était motivée par le fait qu'il se considérait à l'abri de la Jurisprudence locale et justiciable du tribunal

consulaire de France, non seulement en verta I do protectorat, mais S.S. i en vertu de divers décrets en faveur des Maronites, promalga és par les rois de France, confirmés par l'Empire et par la République, et, enfin, reconnus valides par M. Rouvier lors de la réception toute récente de patriarcha maronit) sa quai d'Orsay. 1 L'affaire, de judiciaire, devint bien vite
diplomatique, le jour ou le tribunal transmit i le jugement au gouverneur du Caire pour qu'il

le fit exécuter manu militari. 1 Le conseil de Frano, sisi sa fait, oppor engagement la qualité de moine, protégé français, qui, par con équent, de peut être jugé par les tribunaux indigè se'. | Le gouvernement égyptien ne reconnut pas les prétentions de la Franos. C'est alors que M. de la B Jalinière, ministro de France au Caire, appaya les dirsi da consulat at protesta é vergiquement contre la violation des traités : en même temps, il prévenait le quai d'Orsay. i A l'heure actuelle, l'affaire n'a pas encore reçu de solution

div.head: WOMEN'S MENTAL INFERIORITY.
div.p: In his interesting discourse before the Biological Society, on woman's intellectual position, Dr. Bernard Hollander mentioned that the late Professor Bischoff, of Monich, was oco of the lea ling physiologists of Europa to adopt the hypothesis of the mental inferiority of woman to inın, chiefly on the ground that the average: weight of a man's brain was 47} oz. į or 3 oz more than a woman's. After his death a post-mortem revealed the curious fact that his own brain weighed only 433 oz., or rather ie3: then the weight be assigned to the average woman's brain. As Dr. Hollander contended, it was not so mnoy the size of the entire brain, as the size of that portion in the frontal lobes which governs intellectual capacity.

div.head: THE LATEST FIND.
div.p: It is reported that the excavators under the direction of the Service des Antiqaités at Zawat el-Aryan, near Abusir, have brought to light a magnificent tomb of a king of the somond dynasty. At Deir el-Bahari the work seems to have been confined to the trading of arobitoo toral details, but M. Naville is now on his way thither, and his arrival will no doubt give things an impetus. Prof. Petrie is reported to be at Tell el-Yahudiyeh, bat, 80 far, to have found nothing.'

div.head: Egypt Exploration Fund.
div.p: The Apnaal Archeological Report of the Egypt Exploration And is now out. The cbiof article is M. Naville and Mr. Hall's account of their work at Deir el Bahari, and is well illustrated by photographs. Mach shorter articles by Mr. Nathan Davies, Prof. Petrie, and Dra. Grenfell and Hunt on the different works ei. trusted to them follow; and then comes Mr. Griffith's record of Egyptological work during the past year, which form, as negal, rather dry reading. He is, however, unexpectedly sound in his remarks upon the attempts of the German professors Dr. Mabler, Dr. Meyer, and Dr. Set to "settle," arbitrarily and in a pontifical manner, the lines of Egyptian chronology, and suggests that there are possibly factors in the problem at Qorovul which may get all previous calculations. The reports of Mr. Garstang, Mr. Weigall, M. Lagrain, and Mr. Quibell are incorporated with this part of th: Report, and form, with Mrs. Petrie's story of the work of the Bzyptian Research Account, a tolerably complete record of the excavations of the past year. Many of the publications reviewed have already been noticed, but this part of the work is well and oirefally dove, and with a more evident striving after impartial criticism that Was noticeable in former years. The chapter on Grexo-Roman Egypt by Dr. Keayon is, as usual, a model of what such work should be, but csils for pc special remark; while in Mr. Crum's equally excellent chapter on Christian Egypt we can only notice a very brief, bat sharp and just criticism of some recent work of M. Ravilloat. We are sorry to notice that the chapter on Arab Egypt has this year dropped opt.

div.head: Egypt and Babylonia,
div.p: A notable work by that eminent Egyptologist, Mr. de Morgan, is that just published in L33 Recherche: Archéologiques,' which seems to biva originally appeared in the enterprising publication called La Revue dos Idées. He here marks the distinction between the Babylonian and the Bgyptian records, in that the first names were consciously historical and were written for the sake of posterity, while the last give, as the others do not, scanna from the daily life of the people. He thinką, too, that many of the facts of Babylonian history. may be explained by the theory that the different provinces of Mesopotamia were at one time separated from each other by great traits of water; and he throv: some doubt upon the generally received notion that the Egyptian fellah is a battery work in for explorers than the Chaldean Arab. Having tried many different races, he comes to the conclusion that a few Groak or Italian "oa7vie;" wyald do more work than several times their number of Orientale, and it is not impossible that such ganga may ia time be organised. He also gives detailed instructions for the systematic attack on the site of an ancient town or village, and even suggests several such as likely to yield a profitable crop of antiquities; while he con. olades with a dissertation upon ancient mines, quarries, and lines of communication, with many practical hints on the conveyance and preservation of objects discovered, and some brief remarks on the beat means of publication. If he is a little too much inclined to counsels of perfection, the book is yst one that do working arcbæologist can safely neglect.

div.head: History of Alexandrian Patriarcha.
div.p: A disagreeable instanog of the "rattening" propensities of a certain class of German pro. fogsor h 19 came to light in the attack lately delivered by Prof. Saybold, of Tübingen, upon our countryman Mr. Betta's History of the Patriarchs of Alexandria,' now in course of publication. Prof. Seybold, in a letter to the

Revue Critique," lately uncaged Mr. Evetts of plagiarism, of being & very poor Arabic scholar, of not knowing a word of Coptio, and of other high arobæological crimes and misdemeanours. In a reply to this, which has necessitated the publication of a special supplement to the review named, M. Nau takes on the cudgels in defence of Mr. Evette, and Abow, with chapter and verse, that it is Prof. Seybold, and not Mr. Bvetts, who is in fault. His concluding remark is that there are about Arabia thousands of camel-men and donkey-drivers, who are beiter acquainted with Arabic grammar and literature than the professor who takes upon himself to lecture others. As will be buon from this specimen, Dr. Naa does not mince matters.

div.head: WAR'S ALARMS.
div.p: Whatever may be the truth about the relations between Berlin and Paris, there seems to be no doubt that the depressing rumors that have been in circulation are having pernicious effects in Alsace-Lorraine, which would probably be the cockpit of any arined straggle. It is known about Metz and Strasbourg that the officers instructing recruits have this y sar received orders to "concentrate their work apod essentials," and that this has taken the form of constant gonna practitioner by the recruits with live shells, and rifle practice with hall cartridge. These measures have greatly diatarbed trade in the two provinces, and it has been almost paralysed by the false rumours of a French mobilisation at Nanoy. .

div.head:
LAND IN EGYPT.
POSSIBILITIES OF DEVELOPMENT
div.p: The following article recently appeared in the "Times" :

The extraordinary prosperity of Egypt bas begin to attract the attention of the British public, and the general ignorance which prev. ailed op to a very few years ago with regard to this country is giving place to a desire to know something of its possibilities. In course of time there will probably be a fairly general move. ment to purchase Egyptian securities, but at present the small investor usually regards financial and industrial enterprises in foreign countries with much distrast, partly owing to bitter experience in regard to gold-mining ventures. As a field for the profitable in the vert ment of money, Egypt offers many attractions which are quite known to the general public, both which are becoming familiar to Mary visitors among the thousands who wictor on the Nilo,more especially to those who associate with residents of the country. It is interesting to recall Lord Cromer's remarks of six years ago (Egypt No. 3, 1889) on the investment of capital in Egypt.

"Pour some years after the occupation of Egypt bat little British capital came into the country. This was in some measure due to want of confidence in the political future. In the meanwhile foreign capitalists sought with some Eagerness for Egyptian investments, often with saccos. A sudden and complete change has now taken placo. A very marked disposition has recently been shown to direct the tide of British capital towards Egypt. The tendency is to be welcomed; but inai machi 39 in most cases tb, compliance, and in some C1803 the assistance of the Government is invoked, grave responsibility rests on the latter to avoid encouraging any sound, ill-considered, or purely speculative project. Whilst the influx of British capital into Egypt may do a great deal of good if it is directed into healthy channels, it may on the other hand do inach harm, both to the country, to Bgyptian credit, and to the bona fide investors thetusel var, if the contrary is the case. Simultaneously with the influx of British capital in!o Egypt to which I have alluded above, & somewhat remarkable change has taken place in dative pablia, opinion. Heretofore, native capitalists bare, with some rare exceptions, invested their money almost exclusively in land. Recently, however, a strong disposition has been shown to seek for investments in industrial sod commercial undertakings. The change is on every ground to be welcomed, and the tendency may be encouraged by the Government stipulating, in respect to all such undertakings as are in any degree under its control, that a certain proportion of the share capital board in all future cr998 be reserved for the local market. I am given to understand that this tendency exists notably in respect to all commercial projects brought forward dodear British auspices."
Growth of Limited Companies.

Daring the last seven years eighty.five limit. ed liability companies have been formed to undertake various enterprises in Brypt and the Padan, this total includes twenty-nine mining companies, while twenty-one companies have for their object the purchase and sale or development of agricultural land or building property. Fifty of these companies were found. ed onder Boglish law and have their registered offices in Bogland ; thirty-two were founded in Egypt, and three in Belgium. In regard to limited liability companies founded in Egypt, Lord Cromer drew attention in 1889 to the defective state of Egyptian law, and quoted as follows form & report of M. de Rocca Serra, who had for many years been one of the law officers of the Bgyptian Government :

"In the present state of the law the Bgyptian Government is in theory armed with absolute discretionary power as regards the creation of limited liability companies (sociétés anonymous). and, by reason of the extent of its power, besi. tates to make use of it ; 88 a matter of fact, no authorisation has ever been refused for fear of hindering the industrial and commercial development of Egypt; after examination, permission is always accorded. Bnt this examination is necessarily superficial. Even on the assumption that it were more thoroughly conducted, it may safely be affirmed that the Government is liable to be imposed upon by the skill of Bone anscrap loos agent. Should this be the case, the degree of authorisation gives in some degree official sanction to the propo:al; the public thinks, or at all events is liable to thick, that the undertaking, had been studied in all its details by Government officials, and that it is to some extent patronised by the Government. The result is that, in case of disaster, a certain amount of moral responsibility rests on the State." Lord Cromer then went on to say: — "It cannot be too clearly understood by investors both in Egypt and in Europe that the mere fact of a prospectos appearing with the phrase 'Authorized by Khedivial Decree' or similar words printed on it merely signifies that certain formalities prescribed by the law of Egypt have been fulfilled. The use of this expression does not necessarily imply that the Khedivial Government, crits Brittsb adviser, A8ame any responsibility what. Boever for the absolute accuracy of the facts stated in the prospectos, Still less does it imply that the proposal laid before the public is one which will receive pecuniary support, or even a couragement, from the Government.
Land Companies in Egypt

Most of the land companies operating ' Egypt have numerous opportunities to employ their capital in a very profitable clars of investment, and therefore they constitate at present one of the most interesting features of commercial enterprise from the investor's point of view. But I do not wish it to be inferred that all such companies can claim the confidence of investors. There are good ones and bad, and among the latter is more than one that fails the oven to justify its existence. For example, the public in England was invited a few months ago to subscribe towards the for. mation of the North Egypt Land Company (Limited), whose object was to buy and develop a tract of land in the Mariout district, the sole security for its success being the assumption that the Government might be expected to extend a certain canal to within reach of the property and thus provide the facility for irrigation without which the property is prac. tically valueless. It is well known here that Government has po prosent intention of prolonging the capa!, and that, even in the event of boch a project being carried out, the supply of| water could only be very precarious, and even then that the water would have to be raised a considerable height to get it on the land. To those who are familiar with the country this project appeared from the first to be a hopeless ventare. There have been other land companies floated which, instead of setting to work seriously on goond operations in connexion with lard, building property, or trade, have Used their funds to promote or boleter op gold and other mining corcoran. Generally, I would warn investors (unless they have trustworthy first-hand information) to avoid companies which associate themselves with the Egyptian mining industry.

div.head: QUIRINAL AND VATICAN.
div.p: Since the New Year began an event has occurred which has placed the relations between the kingdom and the Papacy in Italy on & mora common sense footing, and which will no doubt lest to a better understanding between Church and State in Italy. The prefoot Pope Pius X. has been gifted with the faculty of seeing things as they are, which was denied to b's predecessors, and he has accepted a payment of the kingdom towards the expenses of foreign missions, namely Pius IX. and Leo XIII. thought fit to refuse. In 1873 tha I:alina Parliament suppressed the religious orders and dis-endowed them, but, at the same time, it allotted & som of £16,000 for the maintenance of the orders abroad. This sum the Pope released officially, as inconsistent with his pose as a Prisoner in the Vatican. In 1876 the Vicariat begged to be allowed to make use of the money, and 80 the kingdom bugso to make songal payments, which at last amounted to £8,000 per annum. The money was paid, but nothing was said about it in order that the feelings of the Vatican might not be injured. The present Pope is a bater of sbams, and be decided to put the payment on a proper footing. He, therefore, entered into negotiations with the Italian Government on the subject, and though he might have legally claimed all arrears since 1873, with interest, he wisely preferred not to cast goch a slur on the memory of his predecessors, and has accepted an appeal payment of £12,390 in discharge of all liabilities. The difficulties with France have induced the Vatican to draw closer to Italy, and the result has been so to strengthen the hands of the Pope as to enable him to abandon an optenable position.

div.head: WHAT IT COSTS TO BE AN M.P.
div.p: Most men have to pay pretty heavily for the privilege of writing M. P. after their name. Some time ago a member of Parliament, a landowner, representing a county constituency, said that his seat in Parliament cost him on an average £4100 a year, exclusive of the cost of two elections, which necessitated an expenditure of £1100 and £1000 respectively.

"If you were to respond to all the demands made upon you," he said, "your constituents would rob you of every chilling you have. It costs me £4000 a year to respond merely to the moderate demands made upon me. I get on an average from 40 to 50 begging letters a day. Somebody is building & chapel and wants a donation. In another charch the organ is being repaired. A tradesman is on the brink of rain from which a top pound note will save him. A fisherman is drowned, and his widow and orphans want immediate succour. A small farmer has lost his cow and his chief means of support. I, as their representative in Parliament, am expected to meet all these wants and Bubbly all these deficiencies." .

div.head: BRITISH ENGINEERING IN 1905.
div.p: That the traditional characteristics of English engineering materials-excellence of quality and sound and conscientious work manbir--leave during the past year or two of bad fall play in the world's market, is shown by the statistics lately published by the Board of Trade. The "Times Engineering supplement" | remarks:-There was a period, not so long ago, when it was the fashion brosd to represent that British engineering war eclipsed, or in process of being 89, by the superior skill and more scientific methods of our competitor ; and to this cry our national habit of self depreciation materially contributed. There can be no doubt that a twin porary disposition to make * fuller trial of American and German manufactures prevailed in central markets ; And! uther countries reaped a doubtful benefit by the momentary attention given to their claims. Ex: perience, however, which teaches that in the elements of genuineness and reliability the British engineer is unrivalled, resulted in a reaction, the force of which is visible in the Board of Trade Returns.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Caire, 18 janvier. Les cours de Londres sont tongue in variés, à l'exception de celui de l'Unifiée qui porte 1/S de baisse.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier & clátoré, par contre, avec 7 francs de hausse à 80.5.
Ici, le marboré des valeurs a été, ce matin, ferme et quelque peu plus animé que cos jours derniers.
La National Bank a avancé à 25 7/8 l'action ancienne et 25 la nouvelle. L'Agricole s'est inscrite à 9 9/16 l'ancienne et 9 3/32 la nouvelle. La Cassa di Sconto s'est maintenue à 210.
L'action Crédit Poncer & clótaré à 803 avec beaucoup d'affaires. L'obligation à lot, 1883 est remontée 333 ; la nouvelle émission est à 274-275.

L'Immobilière a avancé à 360. L'Enterprise and Development s'est inscrite á 12 1/4, la part de fondateur à 1/4, et l'Improvements Corporation à 4 1/2. La Delta Light & fait 11 5/16. La Land Allotment est revenue à 3 3/4, la part de fondateur & 93. Les actions Tramways d'Alexandrie ont gagné 2 francs à 162. in Le groupe des hôtels est resté oslo et sans changement.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les New Egyptian ont coté 27 sh. 9, les Estates 1 9/16, los Salt and Soda 20 Bb. 3. les Markets 23 sb. et les Investments Abdy 1 1/8.

Suivant les dernières informations d'Alexandrie, la Société Égyptienne d'entreprises urbaines et rurales aurait rompu les négociations avec la Building Lande. Elle traiterait maintenant pour une fusion avec la Société des Immeubles, qui possède une bonne partie des propriétés de la Chérif Pacha. Rien ne serait encore décidé, la Société des Entreprises urbaines et rurales 8 montrant, dit-on, très exigeante.
Ajoutons au sujet de cette société qu'en dehors des dividendes qu'elle distribue sur les actions et les parts de fondateur, elle mettra £ 7 & 8,000 à la réserve.
La même société vient de gagner en première instance le procès de préemption qui lai avait été intenté sur les terrains de la Compagnie da Gas et ceux y attenant.

Ces terrains avaient été acquis au prix de LE. 4 lo pio; or, on offre actuellement à la Société LR 8 le pic Il y aurait lå op bénéfice de LE. 30,000 qui ne serait compte que dans le prochain exercice.
Oa nous écrit de Londres à la date du 12 janvier :

"La souscription aux £150,000 d'obligations 5 % au pair, émises par l'Egyptian Estates Company, a été ouverte aujourd'hui et sera close lundi prochain. L'émission est garantie par une commission de 2 et 1/2 pour cent. On cote nominalement 1/2 A 1 1/2 de prime.

"Relativement à la Banque d'Abyssinie, la liquidation spéciale demandés pour les 7.00) titres alloués à Londres, liquidation qai était sur le point d'être fixée par le comité du Stock Exchange, a été remise. La cause de cet ajournement est que l'inscription n'était pas tout à fait en règle ; les changements, qui y ont été introduits devront être confirmés par la Banque d'Abyssinie, et aussitôt cette confirmation recao, l'affaire reviendra devant le Comité. On entendra alors ceux qui s'opposent à cette liquidation spéciale à cause de leurs ventes pour compte de l'étranger. On est généralement d'avis que los protestataires se trouveront forcés de racheter et que le Comité scoordera la liquidation demandée.
Nous extrayons d'une autre lettre de Lon. dres, on date du 12 janvier, le passage suivant relatif à la situation monétaire :

"L'effet des disponibilités apportées par les coupons de janvier se fait sentir, mais dans d'assez faibles proportions, car il est en partie Neutralisé par la faiblesse de la réserve de la Banque d'Angleterre, par la crainte d'un exode important d'or, notamment vers l'Amérique du Sud, par la situation toujours troublée de marché de New-York, enfia par l'intention attribuée au gouvernement français d'augmenter la limite de la circulation des billets de la Banque de France et, par conséquent, de favoriser les importations d'or.

Aussi bien, en présence de ces conditionné du marché monétaire, les valeurs no se mouvent qae dans des limites extrêmement étroites. Le Stock Exchange est ferme, mais il ne s'en tient pas moins sur la réserve. Il n'a pas encore, en tout cas, la physionomie qu'on espérait lui voir reprendre dans la première quinzaine de janvier."
Les cours du coton arrivant en baisse d'Amérique. Le disponible a perdu hier 5 points, la Mai et Octobre 14 et 6 points respectivement
Les arrivages ont été de 20.000 balles contre 19,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est également en légère ré totia.
Ici le Mir3 a ouvert, ce matin, à 16 pour clôturer au même prix.

MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l'exécution de 'bons ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et New-York. La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyés sur demande.

THEATRE ZIZINIA
LE VOYAGE DE M, PERRICHON
Cette pièce est sans doute la meilleure et la plus amusante de Labiche.
L'acteur nous peint à souhait le bonhomme Perrichon, on Carrossier enrichi. La vulgarité de ses gestes et de ses attitudes, sa façon de parler simple et drôle en font son caractère des mieux définis.
Les scènes de son voyage et de sa vie privée BOLt divertissantes et le dialogue pétille d'esprit, sans toutefois tomber dans la vulgarité.
En somme la comédie de Labiche, bien que déjà vieille, a été bien accueillie du public, gai d'etat fort am08 é.
L'interprétation a été excellente. M. Coquelin Cadet a d'é parfait dans le rôle de Perrichon, qu'il a d'ailleurs interprété des centaines de fois.
M. Coquelin Cadet, qui part aujourd'hui pour la France, a dit à la fin de la représentation qu'il regrettait de quitter Alexandrie, mais qu'il espérait y revenir et y trouver un Nouveau théâtre.

div.head: THEATRE ALHAMBRA
div.p: Lsa Travaux d'Hercule obtiennent décidément un fort beau sauces pour la saison.

Il y avait beaucoup plus de monde hier soir à l'Alhambra que pour l'avant-dernière repré. Mentation, ce qui semble faire supposer que de nouvelles auditions de la pièce seront favorablement accueillies da pablo alex sodrio.
Il faut dire que l'exécution n'a rien laissé à désirer. Mllo Chantonnay a été particulièrement
remarquée pour son entrain et la perfection - avec laquelle elle a joué son rôle.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

World-wide reputation.

Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
